headline.main: Bananas, Maybe. Peas and Kale? Dream On.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a while, Christine Ferrara, a working mother in Millburn, N.J., tried to coax, cajole and coerce her picky 2-year-old, Charlotte, into eating what the family was eating. But after her second child was born, Ms. Ferrara did not have the energy for the nightly battle.
docs.snippet: Should parents of picky eaters be concerned? Experts have a smorgasbord of answers, but surprisingly little research.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Half of all toddlers are picky eaters. How hard should their parents push a balanced diet?

multimedia.caption: Losing the Mealtime Battle
multimedia.credit: Half of all toddlers are picky eaters. How hard should their parents push a balanced diet?

headline.main: The Food Industry And the Obesity Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Whatever one might think about the relative importance of personal, corporate or governmental responsibility in halting the obesity epidemic (''Striking Back at the Food Police,'' June 12), we should all be able to agree on at least one thing: current United States food and agricultural policies do not promote health.

headline.main: The Food Industry And the Obesity Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While anyone can see the increasing girth of the American waistline, we need to place blame where it is due. Personal responsibility is the crux of the issue. Building a bigger, better burger is called capitalism if you can find a market for it. Excuse me, but isn't that one reason we live here?

headline.main: Scrutinizing the State of the African-American Male, and How to Improve It

docs.lead_paragraph: Why are African-American men more likely to wind up in jail, or unemployed or in poorer health than white men? These were just a couple of the questions addressed yesterday at an impassioned conference on the state of the African-American male. The event, held at the New York University School of Law, was convened by members of the Congressional Black Caucus representing local districts. It concentrated on black men in New York and New Jersey, but was part of a nationwide effort to draw attention to the challenges facing black Americans everywhere.
docs.snippet: Why are African-American men more likely to wind up in jail, or unemployed or in poorer health than white men? These were just a couple of the questions addressed yesterday at an impassioned conference on the state of the African-American male.

headline.main: Taking Candy From Schoolchildren Isn't So Easy After All

docs.lead_paragraph: HERE'S a question. Did you have Coke machines in your school lunchroom when you were a kid? Unless you were in school in the mid-1990's, of course you didn't. It never would have occurred to you that you could buy a Coke or Pepsi in school to go with your turkey and mashed potatoes.
docs.snippet: States across the country have found that once soda and candy get in the schools, it's almost impossible to get them out.
